sub_subject.name: Apologetics and Worldviews
sub_subject.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Apologetics and Worldviews (Bible & Theology)

objectives.objective_text: Identify that numbers and logic come from God.
Name Bethlehem as the place God promised Jesus would be born.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Reliability of the Biblical Text
objectives.objective_text: Identify the Bible as a true book, not a fairy tale.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Reliability of the Biblical Text
objectives.objective_text: Name the Scribes as men who copied the Bible carefully.
Identify when someone says something that doesn't make sense.
Name 'silly talk' vs. 'true talk'.
Name God as the one who makes things make sense.
Identify that everyone believes something.
Name God's Word as the boss of truth.
Identify that God made the world because it is beautiful and ordered.
Name God as the First Maker (everything needs a maker).
Identify that the sky and trees tell us God is strong.
Name 'General Revelation' as God speaking through nature.
Identify that God made the world, it wasn't an accident.
Name 'Secular' as living like God isn't there.
Identify that not everyone who says 'Jesus' believes the Bible.
Name the Bible as our only special book.
Identify that God is a Person, not a 'force' or 'energy'.
Name magic and horoscopes as things God hates.
Identify that we are saved by faith, not by doing chores.
Name Jesus as the one we pray to, not Mary or saints.
Identify the Empty Tomb.
Name the eyewitnesses (Mary, Peter, the disciples).
Identify a miracle as something wonderful only God can do.
Name Jesus' power over storms and sickness.
Identify that God knows the future.
Recall that the world didn't happen by accident.
Observe that a watch needs a watchmaker, and the world needs a Creator.
Recall that everyone knows there is a God (Romans 1).
Observe God's power in a storm or a mountain.
Recall that we are made for a purpose.
Observe that people are sad without God.
Recall that Jesus is God, not an angel or a brother of Satan.
Observe that we must be careful who we listen to.
Recall that we pray to God, not crystals or stars.
Observe that Jesus is the only Light.
Recall that the Bible is our boss, not the Pope.
Observe that we love our Catholic neighbors but disagree on how we are saved.
Recall that Jesus ate food after He came back to life.
Observe that the disciples were not afraid anymore.
Recall that miracles showed Jesus was God's Son.
Observe that magic tricks are not miracles.
Recall that Jesus did everything God promised.
Observe that only God can tell what will happen 100% of the time.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Reliability of the Biblical Text
objectives.objective_text: Recall that the stories in the Bible really happened.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Reliability of the Biblical Text
objectives.objective_text: Observe that we have many, many old copies of the Bible.
Recall that we should answer foolishness wisely.
Observe that people who don't know God are confused.
Recall that if there was no God, we couldn't know anything for sure.
Observe that even people who don't love God use God's logic.
Recall that wearing different glasses makes the world look different.
Observe that some people don't believe the Bible.
Summarize the idea of Cause and Effect (The Universe has a Cause).
Explain the Argument from Design (Complexity implies intelligence).
Explain why an infinite regress of causes is impossible.
Defend theism against the 'God of the Gaps' objection.
Summarize Psalm 19 ('The heavens declare the glory of God').
Explain that nature shows God exists, but not how to be saved.
Explain the relationship between Reason and Revelation.
Defend the compatibility of Faith and Reason.
Produce an essay on the necessity of Special Revelation to complete General Revelation.
Summarize what an Atheist believes (No God).
Explain that if there is no God, there is no real right or wrong.
Explain Postmodernism (No absolute truth).
Defend the necessity of God for meaning, value, and purpose.
Summarize the main error of JWs (Jesus is not God).
Explain the main error of Mormons (Adding books to the Bible).
Explain how to share the true Gospel with a cult member.
Defend the biblical definition of the Trinity and Hypostatic Union.
Produce a comparison chart of key doctrines: God, Jesus, Salvation, Scripture.
Summarize the idea of Pantheism (God is everything).
Explain why we don't play with Ouija boards or spirits.
Explain the spiritual danger of the occult (Deuteronomy 18).
Defend the distinct personality of God against Pantheism.
Summarize the 'Five Solas' of the Reformation.
Explain the difference between Grace Alone and Grace + Works.
Explain the error of Purgatory and Indulgences.
Defend the doctrine of Imputation vs. Infusion of righteousness.
Produce an essay on the Mariology dogmas (Immaculate Conception, Assumption).
Summarize the events of Easter morning.
Explain why the disciples wouldn't die for a lie.
Explain why the 'Stolen Body' theory fails.
Defend the bodily nature of the resurrection against spiritualized interpretations.
Produce an essay on the Trilemma (Liar, Lunatic, or Lord).
Summarize why Jesus performed miracles (compassion and proof).
Explain the difference between magic and a miracle.
Categorize miracles (Healing, Nature, Resurrection).
Explain the 'Sign' theology in John's Gospel.
Defend the Resurrection as the 'Grand Miracle' that validates all others.
Produce a reflection on the relationship between faith and evidence.
Summarize the prophecies of the Crucifixion (Psalm 22, Isaiah 53).
Explain how Jesus fulfilled the Passover.
Explain the concept of 'Typological Fulfillment'.
Defend the supernatural origin of the Bible based on predictive prophecy.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Reliability of the Biblical Text
objectives.objective_text: Summarize how we know the Bible hasn't been changed (Manuscripts).

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Reliability of the Biblical Text
objectives.objective_text: Explain that archaeology finds things that match Bible stories.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Reliability of the Biblical Text
objectives.objective_text: Defend the reliability of the New Testament against the 'Da Vinci Code' style conspiracies.
Summarize how to ask 'How do you know that?'
Explain that non-Christians have to 'borrow' Christian ideas (like right and wrong).
Explain how to expose the arbitrariness of non-Christian claims.
Defend the faith by showing that non-Christian systems collapse on their own terms.
Summarize why we can trust our minds (because God made them).
Explain that laws of logic (like math) don't change.
Explain why materialism cannot account for the laws of logic.
Defend the Christian worldview as the only basis for rational thought.
Produce an essay on Van Til's apologetic method.
Summarize what a 'Worldview' is (how we see everything).
Explain that everyone has faith in something (God or themselves).
Explain why evidence alone doesn't convince everyone (Romans 1).
Defend the necessity of the Christian worldview to make sense of anything.
Connect the fear of the Lord to the beginning of knowledge.
Compare a building (needs a builder) to the universe (needs a Creator).
Apply the Moral Argument: We know right and wrong because God exists.
Analyze the Kalam Cosmological Argument (Everything that begins to exist has a cause).
Interpret the Fine-Tuning Argument (anthropic principle).
Connect the existence of objective moral values to a Moral Lawgiver.
Compare what we learn from a sunset vs. what we learn from the Bible.
Apply the truth that no one has an excuse for ignoring God.
Analyze the limits of Natural Theology (cannot reveal the Trinity or Atonement).
Interpret Romans 1:18-20 regarding the suppression of truth.
Connect the order of the universe to the mind of God (Logos).
Compare living for 'now' with living for eternity.
Apply the hope we have in Jesus.
Analyze the worldview of Materialism (only matter exists).
Interpret the logical end of Atheism (Nihilism/Meaninglessness).
Connect Darwinian evolution to the devaluation of human life.
Compare the Trinity with the false views of cults.
Apply the warning to not add or subtract from Scripture.
Analyze the history of Joseph Smith and Charles Taze Russell.
Connect the cults' demand for works to the denial of grace.
Compare the Creator/Creature distinction with the idea that 'we are all gods'.
Apply the command to have no other gods before Him.
Analyze the worldview of Monism (All is One).
Interpret the danger of 'Christ Consciousness' vs. the Person of Christ.
Connect Gnosticism (secret knowledge) to New Age thought.
Compare the Priest in the OT with Jesus our High Priest.
Apply the truth that Scripture is enough (Sola Scriptura).
Analyze the issue of Authority (Scripture vs. Tradition + Magisterium).
Interpret the Roman view of Justification (process) vs. Biblical (declaration).
Connect the Mass/Eucharist to the finished work of Christ.
Compare the Swoon Theory (he fainted) with what really happened.
Apply the fact of the Resurrection to our own hope.
Analyze the 'Minimal Facts' approach (Habermas).
Interpret the conversion of skeptics like James and Paul.
Connect the rise of the early church to the reality of the Resurrection.
Compare the miracles of Jesus with the 'miracles' of other religions.
Analyze the definition of a miracle (divine intervention in natural law).
Interpret Nicodemus' statement: 'No one can do these signs unless God is with him.'
Connect the cessation/continuation debate to apologetics (do miracles happen today?).
Compare vague predictions (horoscopes) with specific Bible prophecies.
Apply the certainty of future promises based on past fulfillment.
Analyze the statistical probability of one man fulfilling all messianic prophecies.
Interpret Daniel's prophecy of the empires.
Connect the destruction of Tyre (Ezekiel) to historical fulfillment.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Reliability of the Biblical Text
objectives.objective_text: Compare the number of Bible copies with other old books.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Reliability of the Biblical Text
objectives.objective_text: Apply confidence in the Bible when others say it is made up.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Reliability of the Biblical Text
objectives.objective_text: Analyze the 'Telephone Game' objection and why it doesn't apply to Scripture.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Reliability of the Biblical Text
objectives.objective_text: Interpret the significance of the Dead Sea Scrolls.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Reliability of the Biblical Text
objectives.objective_text: Connect the short time gap between events and writing to historical accuracy.
Compare a house built on sand (unbelief) vs. rock (Christ).
Apply Proverbs 26:4-5 (Answer a fool according to his folly).
Analyze a worldview to see if it contradicts itself (e.g., 'There is no absolute truth').
Interpret the 'Roof Off' method (Francis Schaeffer).
Connect the lack of a moral standard in atheism to the problem of evil.
Compare a random universe (chaos) with God's universe (order).
Apply the idea that atheists are borrowing from God's world to argue against Him.
Analyze the preconditions of intelligibility (Logic, Morality, Uniformity of Nature).
Interpret the 'Problem of Induction' (why will the sun rise tomorrow?).
Connect the laws of logic to the nature of God (universal, invariant, abstract).
Compare the Christian view (God made us) with the Secular view (we are accidents).
Apply the Bible as the starting point for thinking.
Analyze the concept of a 'Presupposition' (an assumption taken for granted).
Interpret the myth of neutrality (no one is neutral).

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Reliability of the Biblical Text
objectives.objective_text: Explain the difference between a translation and a transmission error.
Evaluate Leibniz's Argument from Contingency (Why is there something rather than nothing?).
Evaluate the impact of Darwinism on the Argument from Design.
Evaluate the problem of evil for the Atheist (no standard of 'good').
Evaluate the psychological structure of cult control.
Evaluate the influence of Eastern Mysticism on Western culture (Yoga/Meditation roots).
Evaluate the doctrine of Papal Infallibility.
Evaluate the 'Hallucination Theory'.
Evaluate the claim that science disproves miracles.
Evaluate the objection that Jesus 'maneuvered' to fulfill prophecy.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Reliability of the Biblical Text
objectives.objective_text: Evaluate Bart Ehrman's critique of textual variants.
Evaluate the inconsistencies in Postmodernism.
Evaluate the 'Impossibility of the Contrary'.
Evaluate why Empiricism and Rationalism fail as ultimate standards.
Interpret the translation errors in the New World Translation (John 1:1).
Construct a formal defense using the Ontological Argument (Anselm/Plantinga).
Synthesize Classical arguments to build a cumulative case for theism.
Construct a historical overview of Natural Theology (Aquinas to Paley).
Construct a critique of Secular Humanism.
Synthesize the Christian worldview as the only one that fits reality.
Construct a theological refutation of Arianism (JWs) and Polytheism (LDS).
Construct a critique of Moral Relativism in New Age spirituality.
Synthesize the biblical view of spiritual warfare regarding the occult.
Construct a historical overview of the Council of Trent.
Construct a legal/historical defense of the Resurrection.
Construct a refutation of David Hume's argument against miracles.
Construct a list of major Messianic prophecies and their NT citations.
Synthesize the argument from prophecy with the argument from miracles.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Reliability of the Biblical Text
objectives.objective_text: Construct a defense of the text based on Bibliographical, Internal, and External tests.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Reliability of the Biblical Text
objectives.objective_text: Synthesize the history of the English Bible and manuscript families.
Construct an internal critique of Materialism (it destroys reason/free will).
Synthesize the 'reductio ad absurdum' method in apologetics.
Construct the Transcendental Argument for God (TAG).
Construct a diagram of the 'Archimedean Point' (Ultimate Authority).
Synthesize the relationship between circular reasoning and ultimate authorities.
